Award.AbstractNarration:
Society's most daunting problems call for new strategies that engage many diverse stakeholders into the design process in order to solve bigger and messier problems. While the Internet makes it easy to find and coordinate people, we need to advance fundamental knowledge and technologies for "collective innovation", where groups collectively explore and refine solutions for big problem spaces. Collective innovation works by breaking problems down into many constituent sub-problems, actively engaging a broad group of stakeholders and potential users, and coordinating people with the disparate knowledge needed to solve each piece of a bigger puzzle. This project will create interactive computer systems to support these processes. The proposed research has the potential to fundamentally improve the way people work collectively to solve challenging problems, from small-scale user interfaces to bigger and messier society-scale challenges and to increase the number of people engaged in innovation, important to achieving national objectives.

More specifically, this project will contribute novel interactive systems to explore three key challenges for advancing collective innovation: 1) how to synthesize large collections of prior research and examples in order to frame appropriate research questions, 2) how to productively select and build on the most promising and creative ideas, and 3) how to effectively engage in large-scale participatory design by gathering feedback from an existing community or harvesting it through crowdsourcing and social media. To guide and motivate the design of these systems, this research builds on (and draws explicit links between) theories of design thinking and collective intelligence. The systems developed will be evaluated in authentic, externally valid settings to identify the real-world patterns that emerge when these processes are integrated. The resulting experimental tools will be released as open source so that other researchers may build on the project's progress. The project also includes significant educational goals: training student researchers in social computing system design, design thinking, and evaluation methods; creating a new graduate course on collective innovation; and scaling up the PI's current design studio course.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This CAREER Award project advanced fundamental knowledge and technologies for collective innovation, where large groups collaboratively explore and refine solutions for complex problem spaces. The project explored novel interfaces for four key challenges: 1) how to synthesize large collections of prior research and examples in order to frame appropriate research questions, 2) how to productively select and build on the most promising and creative ideas, 3) how to effectively engage in large-scale participatory design by gathering feedback from an existing community or harvesting it through crowdsourcing and social media, and 4) how to coordinate effective small group collaborations for creative work. A primary goal throughout the grant period was to empirically evaluate different patterns towards a theoretical model for collective innovation.

In total during the timeframe of the grant, 2015-2020, the project published some 35+ full papers at the top international conferences on human-computer interaction (CHI), computer-supported cooperative work and social computing (CSCW), designing interactive systems (DIS), creativity and cognition (C&C) and other venues. Our papers can be found on our ProtoLab website (protolab.ucsd.edu) and in public repositories for science publications (see https://scholar.google.com/citations?user=ywTbDsQAAAAJ). Highlights include:

EXPERIMENTS:  We ran numerous experiments to understand key factors related to collective innovation, including:

-        group brainstorming and novel approaches to facilitating ideation at different scales of participation (see Siangliulue CSCW 2015, C&C 2015 and UIST 2016; Chan CSCW 2016; Andolina C&C 2017; Chan C&C 2017)

-        crowd-based and peer-based feedback exchange for design and problem solving (see Luther CSCW 2015; Hui HCOMP 2015; Yuan CSCW 2016; Yen DIS 2016; Shannon DIS 2016; Nguyen CSCW 2017; Wauck CHI 2017; Foong CHI 2017; Shannon CHI 2017; Krause CHI 2017; Yen C&C 2017; Kang CHI 2018; Cook CHI 2019; Cheng CSCW 2020)

-        collective synthesis of information e.g., finding themes in qualitative data, or organizing similar ideas from a brainstorming session (see Chan CHI 2016; Mahyar CHI 2018 and DIS 2019)

-        coordination and formation of small teams for collaborative problem solving (see Lykourentzou CSCW 2016 and CSCW 2017; McInnis CSCW 2018; Ahmed C&C 2019; Umbelino CSCW 2020)

 

OPEN-SOURCE SOFTWARE:  Many projects produced software prototypes which we make available as open-source on our lab’s GitHub account (https://github.com/creativecolab/)

-        CommunityCrit: platform that structures micro-activities to facilitate discussion for urban design proposals

-        ProtoTeams: a mobile devise system for organizing co-located networking events

-        Paragon: feedback exchange platform that includes galleries of examples to support more principled feedback

-        IdeateRelate: an online gallery of design examples that visualizes prior ideas in relation to new ideas

-        IdeaGens: a system to support group ideation with visualization tools to support facilitation

-        CrowdCrit: a system for recruiting online crowds to provide structured feedback on visual designs

-        PeerPresents: a system for facilitating in-class peer feedback on student presentations

-        D4SD platform: website and React frontend infrastructure for running design challenges

 

CAREER SUPPORT:  The proposal supported career advancement for a number of postdocs and PhD students who moved on to take tenure-track faculty positions (Kurt Luther, Joel Chan, Narges Mahyar, and Amy Cook to name a few that were directly funded), and dozens of undergraduate researchers from diverse backgrounds, including at least 60% that are women or under-represented minorities.

 

BROADER IMPACT:   In terms of broader impact, this grant led to the launch of a new initiative for community-driven design in San Diego, called Design for San Diego (see ds4d.org), which organizes large scale design challenges and hosts a range of workshops and events for our region. The initiative succeeded in creating broad participation in the San Diego community, including students from K-12 up through continuing education, experts from urban planning and civic design, business leaders, and design professionals. Thousands have participated in our events over two cycles of D4SD.  The initiative will enable our research team to further advance our science goals by proving a petri dish to experiment on format, strategies and tools for collective innovation.
